2014 Cornerstone Packing & Cooling LLC Executive Summary
 
Introduction
The Risk Management Program at CornerStone Packing & Cooling complies with US EPA and Cal ARP requirements. 

This 5 year update provides information on changes since the previous 2009 update. During this time several small expansions occured, regular maintenance and calibration was performed. The system operated without incidents or reportable releases. Distance to Toxic endpoint in the worst case release did not increase since it's based on the largest vessel and not the entire inventory. 

Publication or sharing of OCA portions of RMP materials can be in violation of the Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act (PL106-40). 

1.Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
We at CornerStone Packing & Cooling are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  Our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training demonstrates this commitment.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.


2.The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Our facility's primary activities revolve around large-scale storage and processing of tree fruit, citrus and storage.  This activity is consistent with SIC 0723. Anhydrous ammonia is the major regulated substance present at our facility.  The entire ammonia inventory is attributed to use as a refrigerant. Ammonia (anhydrous) is used as a refrigerant in a closed loop refrigeration system.  The safety systems include an Ammonia a diffusion tank, NH3 detection, emergency ventilation, safety relief valves, redundant controls, emergency shower/eyewash and appropriate cutouts. This is consistent with a Program 3 process.

3.The Worst Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s), including

are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is What if /Checklist.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of 5 years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, CornerStone Packing & Cooling maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  In additoina it has sections on Ammonia Hazards& First Aid, Lock-out/Tag-out, Line & Equipment Opening, Ammonia Unloading, Quality Control and oil draining procedures. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.

Training
CornerStone Packing & Cooling has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are completely competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity
CornerStone Packing & Cooling carries out highly documented inspection & maintenance on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance procedures are carried out by qualified personnel or Refrigeration Contractors with a strong background in maintenance practices.  Specialized training is provided to these personnel as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified during maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management o

f Change
Written procedures are in place at CornerStone Packing & Cooling to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel and all other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change in a process are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the changes.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at CornerStone Packing & Cooling.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
CornerStone Packing & Cooling conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP Rule are being implemented.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
CornerStone Packing & Cooling promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years. Any incidents that release a reportable amount of Ammonia require updating the 5 year Accident History and filing a revised RMP with the EPA.

Employee Participation
CornerStone Packing & Cooling truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information collected as part of the facility's compliance with the RMP

Rule including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Hot Work Permit
At CornerStone Packing & Cooling Hot Work Permit procedures are in place and enforced. Preventing accidents related to welding and cutting while alerting others at the facility that this type of work is occurring are important prevention steps.

Contractors
On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  CornerStone Packing & Cooling has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response to an accidental release of a regulated substance.


5.Five-year Accident History
CornerStone Packing & Cooling has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental releases during this period. Any reportable release requires updating the Accident History within 6 months.

6.Emergency Action Plan
CornerStone Packing & Cooling has a written Emergency Action Plan (EAP) to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  Our employees will not enter a hazardous area. The plan includes all aspects of emergency actions to evaluate the need for addtional resources, provide safety for employees, notify public agencies and effectively support responding resources. We have regular training and encourage questions.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency and safety equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is regularly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency actions. Any changes in Emergency Contact information is reported within 30 days.

7.Planned Changes to Imp

administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario

The worst-case release scenario mandated by the RMP Rule is a standardized hypothetical situation intended to promote dialogue. According to the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration The worst-case situation represents an extremely improbable (and for many facilities impossible) set of circumstances rather than a credible accident scenario. Release quantities and hazard distances derived there from for the worst-case scenario should not be used as a basis for emergency response planning.

To evaluate the worst case and alternative release scenarios for ammonia we have used the methodology given in the Model Risk Management Program and Plan for Ammonia Refrigeration by SAIC.  RMP Comp was used to determine DTE based on a release with the largest vessel full.  Specific details are not provided in the Executive Summary as required in recent rulemaking.

Alternate case scenario has also been evaluated and included. This release was typical for a compressor shaft seal.


4.The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME for pressure vessels and applicable building and fire codes at the time of construction.    The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
CornerStone Packing & Cooling maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all the processes.

rove Safety
Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. Better documentation of our PM activities, and clarification of the emergency ventilation system operations are a few of the steps we want to take to improve safety at our facility.  These changes should be implemented by 6/1/15.
